channel.title: NPR All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Ari Shapiro, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.

item.title: Trump says there's an Israel-Iran ceasefire
item.description: President Trump said Israel and Iran have agreed to a ceasefire, ending 12 days of conflict.

item.title: Supreme Court allows quick third-country deportations, for now
item.description: The Supreme Court blocked a court order requiring 15 days notice — enough time to contact their lawyers — to individuals the Trump administration is trying to deport to countries other than their own.

item.title: Mahmoud Khalil talks with NPR after release
item.description: After 104 days in detention, Columbia University graduate student Mahmoud Khalil talks with NPR about his experience.

item.title: Prosecution rests in Sean Combs trial
item.description: Prosecutors arguing the federal government's case against the music mogul Sean Combs, who is accused of sex trafficking and racketeering conspiracy, are expected to finish questioning their witnesses.

item.title: A kind, no-nonsense nurse helped a couple prepare for death
item.description: Eric Johnson's husband Dennis Hopkins was given a 50% chance of surviving lung cancer. During one hospital stay they met their unsung hero, a nurse named Sherry.

item.title: A deaf mom shares her long journey to graduation in college commencement address
item.description: A single mom who is deaf overcame challenges and gave her college's commencement address in Colorado.

item.title: A new observatory in Chile releases some of its first images
item.description: The powerful Vera C. Rubin Observatory is releasing some of its first images as part of an ambitious effort to effectively create a movie of all the changes in the southern night sky over a decade.

item.title: The ghost fleet of the Potomac
item.description: Sometimes history lies hidden just around the corner. Just south of Washington, D.C., is a graveyard with more than 100 wooden ships that date to World War I -- the Ghost Fleet of Mallows Bay.

item.title: Sea lions return home after toxic algae exposure
item.description: After the longest toxic algal bloom on record off the southern California coast, marine mammal researchers are investigating how sea lions were affected, and releasing the last few back into the wild.

item.title: The Middle East conflict could affect a vital waterway for world energy supplies
item.description: Iran has threatened to close the Strait of Hormuz in response to the U.S. bombings of its nuclear facilities over the weekend. The narrow waterway is a vital pathway for world energy supplies.
